name: Summer and Smoke
description:
In a small town in the heat of summer, Alma Winemiller, the minister's daughter, meets John Buchanan, the reckless and intoxicating doctor next door.

As summer deepens and their longing for one another intensifies, desire, duty, and convention collide, dangerously blurring the line between passion and ruin.

Blistering, poetic, and rapturous, this rarely-staged 20th-century masterpiece is Tennessee Williams at his most heart-rending.

name: By the Lake Book Club – 6-Event Package
description:
Enjoy all six By the Lake Book Club events of 2026 for just $120. Join Humber Polytechnic alumni as they dive into conversation with leading Canadian authors. The series line-up features Maggie Helwig, Patty Krawec, Martha Bátiz, Claire Cameron, Emma Knight and Anne Michaels. Each event includes a reading, discussion, audience Q&A, book-signing and American sign language interpretation.

By the Lake Book Club hosts six Tuesday-night events from February to December with top Canadian authors and Humber Polytechnics alumni. Each in-person event features readings, discussions, Q&A, book signings and ASL interpretation, while virtual sessions include live subtitles and audio access.

Maggie Helwig - February 3, 2026 at 7 p.m.
Patty Krawec - March 10, 2026 at 7 p.m.
Martha Bátiz - April 14, 2026 at 7 p.m.
Claire Cameron - September 15, 2026 at 7 p.m.
Emma Knight - October 6, 2026 at 7 p.m.
Anne Michaels - December 8, 2026 at 7 p.m.

name: Encampment: Resistance, Grace, and an Unhoused Community by Maggie Helwig - By the Lake Book Club
description:
Encampment: Resistance, Grace, and an Unhoused Community, by 2025 Toronto Book Award winner Maggie Helwig, chronicles the encampment that formed on the grounds of St. Stephen-in-the-Fields Church during Toronto's housing crisis. Blending memoir, urban history and social critique, Helwig – an Anglican priest and activist – offers an unflinching look at systemic failures and the resilience of those forced to live outdoors.

By the Lake Book Club hosts six Tuesday-night events from February to December with top Canadian authors and Humber Polytechnics alumni. Each in-person event features readings, discussions, Q&A, book signings and ASL interpretation, while virtual sessions include live subtitles and audio access.

name: Beyond the Basics Winter Tree Identification Workshop at Earlscourt Park

location.name: Earlscourt Park – Joseph J. Piccininni Community Centre

description:
Do you already have some experience identifying trees in the winter or looking for more practice identifying trees? Join us for our 'Beyond the Basics' winter tree identification workshop at Earlscourt Park, where we'll dive deeper into the details of winter tree identification. 

We'll take a closer look at trees within the park, as well as examples during our indoor instructional period, noting key identification features like bark, twig arrangement and winter buds. We'll explore winter ID tools/resources and work through the identification of different tree species in Toronto.

This workshop will have an indoor instructional component as well as an outdoor component. Please dress for the weather to stay warm and prepare for uneven and slippery terrain. Tour distances will range from 1 – 5 km.

Space is limited. Please register in advance at greentoronto@toronto.ca to secure a spot to attend. Include the name of the park tour you would like to attend and the number of attendees.
